author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Who Gets to Ski?
description: The mountains are too crowded. The sport is too expensive. Several resorts are trying to fix a number of problems. How are they doing?
content: When Tim Pham learned to ski in the 1980s, the sport seemed simpler. He would go to quiet resorts in Northern California like Sugar Bowl, where he would show up any time of day, buy a $35 lift pass, and ski without facing lines or crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: A Jamaican bobsledder filed an appeal over the women’s qualifying process.
description: She argues that the sport favors European athletes over those from smaller countries elsewhere.
content: Jazmine Fenlator-Victorian, a bobsledder who served as one of Jamaica’s flag-bearers during Friday’s opening ceremony, filed an appeal Saturday morning with the Court of Arbitration for Sport, arguing that a ranking decision by her sport’s governing body favored European athletes to compete at the Olympics and discriminated against athletes from smaller countries elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Leader’s Death Is Another Blow for ISIS, but It’s Hardly the End
description: The Islamic State is a shadow of its former self. But it’s likely to keep adapting and enduring, even after the U.S. raid that killed its top commander.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For a man who sought to disappear, the leader of the Islamic State seemed to have done everything right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whitney Bauck
title: Did Your Handbag Help Destroy the Rainforest?
description: A recent report examines the links between fashion brands and Amazon deforestation.
content: The rainforest and the runway may seem worlds apart, but deforestation in the Amazon is partly fueled by something that’s on display in every fashion capital this month: leather. A New York Times investigation published in November established the connection between deforestation and American appetites for leather in luxury cars, but the problem goes beyond the auto industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Sam Lay, Drummer Who Backed Blues Greats and Bob Dylan, Dies at 86
description: His distinctive double-shuffle groove, which he likened to “three different drummers playing the same beat,” enlivened records by Howlin’ Wolf and many others.
content: Sam Lay, a powerful and virtuosic drummer who played and recorded with Howlin’ Wolf and Muddy Waters, was a founding member of the Paul Butterfield Blues Band and backed Bob Dylan when he went electric at the Newport Folk Festival in 1965, died on Jan. 29 at a nursing facility in Chicago. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Two men in Miami stole 192 ventilators, worth $3 million, the authorities say.
description: The crime occurred in the first year of the pandemic, according to U.S. attorneys in Florida, and involved equipment that the U.S. was sending to El Salvador to treat critically ill Covid patients.
content: Two men in Miami have each been sentenced to 41 months in prison for stealing medical ventilators bound for a Covid-19 care facility in El Salvador as part of a U.S. aid program, federal authorities in Florida said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Raymond Zhong
title: Beijing Wanted the Winter Olympics. All It Needed Was Snow.
description: The environmentally unfriendly secret of winter sports is that many competitions take place on artificial snow. China’s water-scarce capital had to go to enormous lengths to make enough of it.
content: BEIJING — China did not move mountains to host the 2022 Winter Olympics. But it flooded a dried riverbed, diverted water from a key reservoir that supplies Beijing and resettled hundreds of farmers and their families, all to feed one of the most extensive snow-making operations in the history of the Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The Morning: Why we travel
description: We travel not just to escape, but to find novelty, new heights and new sensations.
content: It’s a pleasure to welcome you to the new Saturday edition of The Morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Planning for the 2026 Winter Games is already underway.
description: Milan and Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy, will host the next event, where two million visitors are expected.
content: First, Beijing 2022. Then, Milano Cortina 2026.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
title: Truck Protest Against Pandemic Measures Spreads Across Canada
description: A demonstration that began last weekend in Ottawa against vaccine mandates expanded on Saturday, and others took place in Toronto and Quebec City.
content: OTTAWA — Thousands of protesters across Canada took to the streets on Saturday for the second weekend in a row, snarling traffic, disrupting business and residential neighborhoods and leading the police to compare the demonstrations to a “siege” on the nation’s democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sohrab Ahmari, Patrick Deneen and Gladden Pappin
title: Hawks Are Standing in the Way of a New Republican Party
description: Conservatives must make a clear break with neo-neoconservative foreign policy.
content: A painful contradiction lies at the heart of the American right. Even as conservatives are breaking with some Cold War orthodoxies on domestic policy, Republican politicians remain wedded to that era’s violently expansionist foreign policy. They oppose liberal imperialism in the United States —the aggressive push to impose progressive values, often joined to corporate power — while still contriving to spread the same order to the ends of the earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: A U.S. speedskater, kept at home by Covid tests, hopes to make it to Beijing.
description: Casey Dawson had qualified in two individual events, but test results have prevented him from leaving for the Games.
content: Casey Dawson, an American speedskater, first tested positive for Covid-19 three weeks ago. What followed has been “an emotional roller coaster,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: A rare sight at the Olympics: the Russian flag.
description: The banned item made an appearance as the Russian Olympic Committee faced the United States in a preliminary women’s hockey match.
content: They were not in the rafters or on the benches or jerseys, but Olympic relics surfaced during a women’s hockey game on Saturday night: Russian flags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: What’s Going on With Vaccines for Kids Under 5?
description: It’s confusing, but don’t freak out.
content: I was surprised to see the news this week that the F.D.A. may be getting closer to authorizing a Covid vaccine for children under 5. Why surprised? Because Pfizer and its partner, BioNTech, put out a less-than-crystal-clear news release in December, helpfully encapsulated by The Times’s Apoorva Mandavilli and Rebecca Robbins, suggesting that in trials, two three-microgram doses of their Covid vaccine did not produce the desired immune response in children ages 2 to 5. At the time, the companies said they were evaluating a third dose administered two months after the first two to see if it increased the efficacy of the series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Simmons and Amanda Holpuch
title: Three Dead and One Wounded in Shooting Near Milwaukee, Police Say
description: A gunman, who took his own life, fired at police officers from the second floor of an apartment building in Brown Deer, Wis., after fatally shooting two other people.
content: BROWN DEER, Wis. — A gunman shot three people, killing two, before taking his own life on Saturday at an apartment building in Brown Deer, Wis., a village near Milwaukee, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Ottawa Residents Fed Up With Truckers’ Noisy and Intimidating Occupation
description: Although the focus has been on protests in front of Parliament, three Ottawa neighborhoods have also been upturned by the demonstrations.
content: Just over a week has passed since a convoy of heavy trucks, pickup trucks and cars began their noisy, intimidating and unlawful, according to the police, occupation of Ottawa’s downtown core.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: A Skating Legend Powered by Slights, Real and Perceived
description: Ireen Wüst willed herself to become the world’s best speedskater. She arrives in Beijing chasing a gold medal in her fifth straight Olympics.
content: The thought of the chocolate bar still makes Ireen Wüst smile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: A D.C. bar that was closed after defying vaccination requirements has a new life as a conservative rallying point.
description: Senator Rand Paul and other Republicans are lionizing The Big Board, a family-owned bar a mile from the U.S. Capitol.
content: Days before the first phase of Washington’s vaccination entry requirement went into effect on Jan. 15, The Big Board, a family-owned bar in the popular H Street Corridor, tweeted that it would “always” be open to everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman, Nate Schweber and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Decades Adrift in a Broken System, Then Charged in a Death on the Tracks
description: Martial Simon, mentally ill and homeless, spent years in and out of hospitals before being accused of shoving Michelle Go in front of a subway train.
content: To the homeless men lined up outside Holy Apostles Soup Kitchen in Manhattan, Martial Simon was a familiar figure: often incoherent, usually angry about something.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: The first medals are awarded in Beijing as competition enters full swing.
description: The first full day of events brought an upset. Karen Chen is set to skate for the United States and Jamie Anderson aims for her third straight gold medal in snowboarding.
content: The first medals have been awarded in Beijing, with host China securing its first gold medal of the Games and an underdog competitor turning in an unlikely first-place finish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Battling an Ancient Scourge
description: In “Phantom Plague: How Tuberculosis Shaped History,” Vidya Krishnan explores one of the world’s most infectious and dangerous diseases.
content: PHANTOM PLAGUEHow Tuberculosis Shaped HistoryBy Vidya Krishnan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Tait
title: Bosses of the World, the Office Party Is Not for You
description: Just let your employees party in peace.
content: Through the first year of a pandemic that killed more than 100,000 Britons and locked down millions of others, Boris Johnson, Britain’s prime minister, was in the mood to party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vo Kieu Bao Uyen, Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
title: A Side-Effect of China’s Strict Virus Policy: Abandoned Fruit
description: The closure of Chinese land borders and the tightened screening of goods have driven Southeast Asian fruit farmers into debt. Many have had to abandon their harvest.
content: HANOI, Vietnam — At Pham Thanh Hong’s dragon fruit orchard in Vietnam, most of the lights are turned off. All is silent except for the periodic thud of the ripe pink fruit falling to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Don’t Touch. Don’t Even Look. Invest Like Your Senators Should.
description: Stocks are swinging all over the place. It’s a good time to take your hands off the wheel — here’s how to let go.
content: Perhaps you’ve lost some money betting on stocks, like MetaZuckerbook, and you feel you ought to do something in the face of a wildly swinging market where a giant company can soar or lose a quarter of its value in a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Sci-Fi Showdown
description: Galactic forces collide in this far-out Stephen McCarthy puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is Stephen McCarthy’s third extravagant Sunday puzzle for The Times in less than a year, a trend interrupted by one Thursday last December. He’s such a prolific themed constructor, he must be one of those makers who dreams in themes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: What Is Biathlon? It’s Cross-Country Skiing With Guns.
description: The shooting aspect is a wild card in a cross-country ski race, requiring athletes to use drastically different skill sets.
content: Follow our Olympics 2022 Live coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean, Brenda Kiven and Tom Saater
title: Amid Coups and Covid, Africa Focuses on What’s Most Important: Soccer
description: Many countries competing in the Africa Cup of Nations are enduring security, economic and political crises, but the tournament offers visions of unity, solidarity and joy.
content: YAOUNDÉ, Cameroon — She had watched some of the matches secretly, volume turned down low so that nobody would report her. She had seen the threats, and knew that she could be kidnapped or killed for watching the African soccer tournament that her country, Cameroon, was hosting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: The Mile High Club, Complete With Membership Cards
description: Love Cloud, an airplane charter business, offers private flights that help couples take their relationships (and relations) to new heights.
content: For $995, Love Cloud will fly you and a partner in a private airplane for 45 minutes so that you can have sex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: ‘It Wasn’t an Easy Decision’: Brian Flores Talks About His Lawsuit Against the N.F.L.
description: The former coach accuses the league of discrimination.
content: On Tuesday, the former Miami Dolphins head coach Brian Flores filed a class-action lawsuit against the N.F.L. and its 32 member teams, citing discriminatory hiring practices against Black coaches. He alleges that “the N.F.L. remains rife with racism, particularly when it comes to the hiring and retention of Black head coaches, coordinators and general managers.” (In a statement, the N.F.L. said that the league is “deeply committed to ensuring equitable employment practices.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Todd Gitlin, a Voice and Critic of the New Left, Dies at 79
description: He earned his stripes in the antiwar movement of the 1960s. In his later years, he was often critical of his erstwhile kindred spirits.
content: Todd Gitlin, whose immersion in the student rebellions of the 1960s laid the foundation for his later work as a writer, a cultural historian and both a voice and a critic of the left, died on Saturday in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: ‘Guernica’ Antiwar Tapestry Is Rehung at U.N.
description: The canvas replica of Picasso’s painting, symbolizing war’s horrors, had been a photogenic fixture at the United Nations for decades before its owner, the Rockefeller family, removed it last year.
content: When a 25-foot tapestry replica of Pablo Picasso’s antiwar painting “Guernica” was removed from the United Nations by its owner a year ago after more than three decades there, diplomats mourned the abrupt exit of an artwork that poignantly reflected the organization’s core purpose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Mikaela Shiffrin and Aleks Kilde Are Ski Racing’s Power Couple
description: The American and Norwegian, each multiple gold medal threats, got serious during the pandemic, as Kilde helped Shiffrin rediscover her love of skiing after her father died.
content: Ask Mikaela Shiffrin how she and Aleksander Aamodt Kilde, a Norwegian Alpine star, became ski racing’s power couple and she chuckles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Inyoung Kang and Lauren McCarthy
title: U.S. broadcast coverage continues with freestyle skiing and hockey.
description: The first medals in biathlon, short track and skiing events at the Beijing Games will be up for grabs.
content: U.S. broadcast coverage of the first full day of the 2022 Winter Games includes medal events in speedskating, ski jumping and short track, while the curling and hockey tournaments continue. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Southwest plans to start selling alcohol on flights again, over the objections of flight attendants.
description: A flight attendants’ union said the decision was “unsafe and irresponsible.”
content: Southwest Airlines said Friday that it planned to start serving alcohol on flights later this month, nearly two years after it suspended the service amid coronavirus pandemic restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: New tricks, new countries, new records at the Beijing Olympics.
description: Record-setting appearances include a 49-year-old German speedskater who will become the oldest woman to compete at a Winter Games.
content: Sure, medal counts are an important measure of success at the Olympics. But how about skiing for a country that has no snow?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Do I Know if My Building Is Unprepared for a Fire?
description: We spoke with an expert about how residents can keep an eye on their buildings and make sure their homes are safe and up to code.
content: Q: The recent tragic fire in the Bronx has left many New Yorkers wondering about fire safety in their own buildings. What safety measures should be in place in an apartment building, and how do residents make sure they have them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Aida Alami and Mona El-Naggar
title: Effort to Rescue a 5-Year-Old Transfixes Morocco, Only to End Sadly
description: The four-day rescue operation failed to save the life of Rayan, who plunged down a 100-foot well, a devastating outcome to the many Moroccans who were captivated by the effort to save him.
content: CAIRO — The vigil had lasted for four days, transfixing tens of thousands of people around the world who watched, tweeted, cheered and prayed as a small band of rescuers in a tiny Moroccan village tried to free a 5-year-old boy from the deep well into which he had plunged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Novak and Andrew Higgins
title: Facing Tough Election, Orban Turns to Putin for Support
description: The Hungarian leader made his name by defying Moscow. But he has increasingly turned toward Russia in an effort to secure the natural gas he needs to keep energy prices low and voters happy.
content: BUDAPEST — Facing a tough election in two months, Hungary’s far-right populist prime minister, Viktor Orban, last week opened the centerpiece of a new state-funded museum district celebrating his country’s role as an anchor of European culture and identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Chris Buckley
title: China wins its first gold of the Games in a new mixed-gender short-track event.
description: Fans cheered wildly — despite a pandemic-related no-cheering rule — as the host country won a medal on the first full day of competition.
content: With a flash of a skate, China won its first medal of the Beijing Winter Olympics on Saturday, which was also the first gold medal in a new Olympic event: the short-track speedskating mixed-gender team relay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Editor in Kashmir Is Arrested Amid Intensifying Clampdown
description: The police accused Fahad Shah, who edits a news website, of “uploading anti-national content.” Critics say journalists in Kashmir have increasingly been harassed and intimidated.
content: NEW DELHI — The editor of a news website has been arrested in Kashmir, in what critics called the latest example of a wave of harassment of journalists by the authorities in the troubled region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: On Whoopi Goldberg’s Comments and the Origins of Racism
description: Looking at the history and purpose of race in the modern world.
content: I try to stay away from most hot-button cultural controversies, and that was my plan for the recent contretemps over Whoopi Goldberg’s comments concerning the Holocaust on “The View.” But there’s been some great commentary on it, and I thought I would make a few observations as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Esper Memoir of Trump Tenure to Move Ahead After Legal Battle Ends
description: The former defense secretary dropped a lawsuit against the Defense Department after it reversed decisions on what parts of his memoir were to be redacted, his lawyer said.
content: A memoir by the former defense secretary, Mark T. Esper, about his tenure in the Trump administration will be published with “minimal redactions” after he sued the agency he once led because it wanted to block information in the manuscript, his lawyer said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Therese Johaug of Norway wins the first gold medal of the 2022 Olympics.
description: The American Jessie Diggins comes in sixth, nearly a minute behind the winner.
content: Therese Johaug of Norway won the first gold medal of the Beijing Games on Saturday, dominating the 15-kilometer skiathlon after opening a commanding lead midway through the race that determines the world’s best all-around skier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Ecuador Court Gives Indigenous Groups a Boost in Mining and Drilling Disputes
description: The ruling, which requires the government to seek consent for new projects, could put the brakes on the president’s plan to increase oil production.
content: In a victory for Indigenous communities in Ecuador, the country’s highest court ruled on Friday that they must have a far stronger say over oil, mining and other extractive projects that affect their lands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Afghan Refugees Face Two-Tier System in Europe
description: Educated elites evacuated to Europe after the Taliban’s return are welcomed, but they struggle with their lives in exile, even as their poorer compatriots are shunned.
content: Some of the Afghan women around the table in the neoclassical building in central Athens were making notes in leatherbound notebooks as they debated the future of women and girls in their homeland. They were legislators, journalists and judges — but they were also refugees, a characterization that many of them winced at with shame and disbelief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: U.S. snowboarder Jamie Anderson qualifies for the slopestyle final.
description: A third gold medal may be a tall order. The top rider this season has been Zoi Sadowski-Synnott of New Zealand, who beat Anderson two weeks ago at the X Games.
content: Even a snow-block version of the Great Wall could not protect the athletes from the cold wind that blew through Saturday’s slopestyle competition at Genting Snow Park in Zhangjiakou.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Martine Colette, Who Rescued Exotic Animals, Is Dead at 79
description: Her wildlife sanctuary just outside Los Angeles was among the first of its kind and was supported by Hollywood luminaries.
content: Martine Colette, the founder of Wildlife Waystation, a sanctuary for exotic animals that ran for 43 years just outside the Los Angeles city limits, died on Jan. 23 at a hospital at Lake Havasu, Ariz. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Arizona’s Right Wing Sought Power to Overturn Votes. Rusty Bowers Said No.
description: The speaker of the Republican-controlled Arizona House — who supported Donald J. Trump in 2020 — just torpedoed a bill that would have let lawmakers reject the results of an election.
content: It is a dark time in the life of the American experiment. The world’s oldest democracy, once assumed to be unbreakable, often appears to be coming apart at the rivets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: The Right One Can Produce a Smile
description: Turn that frown upside down! We get Kameron Austin Collins on a Saturday.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Color me stunned when I looked up the last Kameron Austin Collins puzzle for The New York Times and learned that it was way back on July 3, 2021, another Saturday. I have been solving his New Yorker puzzles, which have a different flavor but are also very tough and satisfying. For me, today’s grid is easiest solved from right to left, and getting through it was enough — not too hard, not too quick, just right. If anything, it made me hungry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Why ‘Trust Us’ Is Often Reason Enough Not to Trust the Government
description: In the most sensitive government operations, the public can be beholden to the official narrative — which sometimes turns out to be wrong. Yet officials can be defensive about skepticism from the news media.
content: WASHINGTON — The dramatic national security stories recounted in two official news briefings on Thursday centered on very different subjects, but they featured the same indignant pushback to questioning reporters: just trust us, unless you are more inclined to believe America’s enemies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Adrien Brody Returns to His First Love: Painting
description: The actor creates a skull painting at a borrowed artist’s studio in Brooklyn.
content: The aqua slapped onto the canvas first. Then white, cobalt and cotton candy pink. Yellow blurted on with a rude noise, followed by red and black. This was on a frigid morning in a borrowed art studio in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn. In a crumbly brick building along the industrial waterfront, the actor Adrien Brody knelt on a drop cloth, smearing and swirling paint with a plastic card until it formed patterns, layers and streaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: All Options Are Not on the Table as Biden Moves Troops Closer to Ukraine
description: The president’s opposition to sending U.S. troops into Ukraine reflects the mood of a war-wary Washington, as well as concerns about Russia’s nuclear arsenal.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden flexed America’s military power in hopes of deterring a Russian invasion of Ukraine with his announcement this week that 3,000 U.S. troops were heading to Eastern Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Man Charged in Kidnapping of Bloomberg’s Housekeeper From Colorado Ranch
description: The man was accused of kidnapping an employee of Mr. Bloomberg, the former New York City mayor, and asking for the whereabouts of his daughters.
content: An armed man broke into the Colorado ranch of the former Democratic presidential candidate Michael R. Bloomberg and kidnapped a housekeeper, asking her for the whereabouts of Mr. Bloomberg’s two adult daughters, the authorities said in court documents filed this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Robert Gebeloff
title: Amid Slowdown, Immigration Is Driving U.S. Population Growth
description: A declining birthrate and pandemic deaths helped drive U.S. population growth to historic lows. But immigration appears to be back on the rise.
content: Overall, 2021 will go down as the year with the slowest population growth in U.S. history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Joseph Goldstein
title: How New York City’s Hospitals Withstood the Omicron Surge
description: The highly contagious coronavirus variant stretched the city’s health care system to the breaking point, but not past it.
content: More than 60,000 New York City residents tested positive for the coronavirus in a single day. Testing lines stretched for hours, and a quarantine hotel program doubled in size. Packed emergency rooms had too few nurses. Hospital morgues became so full that about 200 bodies had to be relocated by the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Shaun White reaffirms snowboarding’s worst-kept secret: This is his last Games.
description: White, 35, had previously said he would end his Olympic career in Beijing. On Saturday, he said the Games will mark his retirement from competition.
content: The Beijing Olympics will be Shaun White’s final competitive ride in the halfpipe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Dinosaur Prints in Utah Are Feared Damaged by Construction Equipment
description: Federal work on a new walkway at the site has been halted after paleontology groups raised the alarm about equipment “driven directly over the fossil dinosaur tracks.”
content: In a stretch of remote scrubland north of Moab, Utah, visitors can walk a path across the same land dinosaurs roamed millions of years ago, and peer down at the footprints and other marks the prehistoric beasts left behind, still visible, though turned to stone.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Friends Say Flores, in Suing the N.F.L., Is Walking the Walk
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 5, 2022.
content: “We stand on the precipice of having more African Americans on the United States Supreme Court than as head coaches in the N.F.L. That is outrageous.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Race, Crash, Surgery, Rehab. Then Repeat.
description: Nearly every Olympic skier gets hurt at some point, given that they speed down an icy slopes, sometimes at 80 miles per hour. Advances in orthopedic medicine ensure that most find a way back.
content: BEIJING — The life-size bust sits on a pedestal just inside the lobby of American skiing’s headquarters in Park City, Utah, a solitary bronze celebration of a singular figure in the sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Long-Track Speedskating: How It Works and Who’s Worth Watching
description: Among the top skaters, Americans like Brittany Bowe and Joey Mantia will take on Dutch powerhouses like Irene Schouten and Thomas Krol.
content: BEIJING — Long-track speedskating is the running of the Winter Olympics, with skaters gliding around a 400-meter oval in sprints (500 meters is the shortest race) and distance events (10,000 meters is the longest).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: The Pandemic Has Made Many Seniors Less Active
description: Health experts are concerned that the pandemic, in upending daily routines, has reduced mobility and physical conditioning in older adults.
content: In normal times, Cindy Myers, an executive at a nonprofit organization, is “not a real physical person,” she said. “I work at desk jobs. I’m not a big exerciser.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Rivalries to Watch at the Beijing Olympics
description: The difference between gold and silver might come down to these head-to-head matchups.
content: Follow our Olympics 2022 Live coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Their Fearlessness Inspires Us, but They Showed Us Their Fears
description: A multimedia project reveals the vulnerable sides of Winter Olympic athletes.
content: Usually, you see André Höflich, a 24-year-old Olympic halfpipe snowboarder from Germany, in a sea of snow as he tears daringly down a mountain. But in a recent video interview for The Times, he sits in a dark room and speaks directly to the camera: “If we didn’t have fear,” he says, “we would all be dead by now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Earnings Are Driving the Market but It’s Not Clear Where
description: The stock market has begun swinging wildly as companies like Google, Facebook, Apple, Starbucks and Exxon Mobil reveal their earnings and hint at divergent prospects for the year ahead.
content: The stock market’s swings over the last few weeks have been enough to give you whiplash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: Ukraine Gave Up a Giant Nuclear Arsenal 30 Years Ago. Today There Are Regrets.
description: When the Soviet Union collapsed, Ukraine turned over thousands of atomic weapons in exchange for security guarantees from Russia, the United States and other countries.
content: At the end of the Cold War, the third largest nuclear power on earth was not Britain, France or China. It was Ukraine. The Soviet collapse, a slow-motion downfall that culminated in December 1991, resulted in the newly independent Ukraine inheriting roughly 5,000 nuclear arms that Moscow had stationed on its soil. Underground silos on its military bases held long-range missiles that carried up to 10 thermonuclear warheads, each far stronger than the bomb that leveled Hiroshima. Only Russia and the United States had more weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Inyoung Kang
title: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage on Saturday includes figure skating, snowboarding and skiing.
description: Americans will compete for gold medals in the women’s slopestyle final and the men’s downhill.
content: Broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues in the United States on Saturday evening with medal events in figure skating, snowboarding and Alpine skiing, and, in a theme that will continue for the rest of the Olympics, more curling. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Luke Broadwater
title: In Scrutinizing Trump and His Allies, Jan. 6 Panel Adopts Prosecution Tactics
description: The House committee investigating the assault on the Capitol and what led to it is employing techniques more common in criminal cases than in congressional inquiries.
content: The House select committee scrutinizing the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol is borrowing techniques from federal prosecutions, employing aggressive tactics typically used against mobsters and terrorists as it seeks to break through stonewalling from former President Donald J. Trump and his allies and develop evidence that could prompt a criminal case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: At This Point, I’ll Bet on Susan Collins Over the Resistance
description: Some unheroic realism from Republicans might foster the most important response to the events of Jan. 6.
content: Here are two anecdotes from the still-unspooling saga of Jeff Zucker, no longer the head of CNN. First, from the aftermath: According to The Los Angeles Times, in a meeting between some of the network’s staffers and its corporate leadership, the CNN correspondent Jamie Gangel shared that four members of the congressional committee investigating Jan. 6 had called to say that Zucker’s exit left them “devastated for our democracy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: A judge lets seven Virginia school districts keep their mask policies in place.
description: A judge in Virginia on Friday handed down a temporary ruling that seven school districts could keep their mask mandates in place — a setback to Gov. Glenn Youngkin, who had signed an executive order making masks optional in public schools.
content: A judge in Virginia on Friday handed down a temporary ruling that seven school districts could keep their mask mandates in place — a setback to Gov. Glenn Youngkin, who had signed an executive order making masks optional in public schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Jan. 6 Was a Warning. Will Lawmakers Do Anything to Protect the 2024 Election?
description: The Electoral Count Act needs fixing. Now.
content: The transfer of political power is perhaps the most delicate moment in the life of a democracy. It follows an election which the party in power lost and its opponents won. Inevitably, feelings are raw, tempers are short, and mistrust can run high … all as control of the nation is changing hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Where Fox News and Donald Trump Took Us
description: Roger Ailes understood the appeal Mr. Trump had for Fox viewers. He didn’t foresee how together they would redefine the limits of political discourse.
content: When Roger Ailes ran CNBC in the mid-1990s, he gave himself a talk show called “Straight Forward.” It long ago vanished into the void of canceled cable programs and never received much attention after the network boss moved on to produce more provocative and polarizing content as chairman of Fox News. But “Straight Forward” was a fascinating window into what kind of people Mr. Ailes considered stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: Michael Lewis Revisits ‘Liar’s Poker’
description: The book documented the reckless, frat-guy culture of investment banking in the 1980s. DealBook talked with Mr. Lewis about how Wall Street has (and hasn’t) changed since.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Bringing Health Food to the Masses, One Delivery at a Time
description: Thrive Market has found success with a subscription model and eco-friendly, health-conscious brands. It’s a diet familiar to the C.E.O., Nick Green.
content: As a kid growing up in the Minneapolis suburbs during the ’90s, Nick Green’s kitchen cupboard was not like his friends’ kitchen cupboards. There were no salty snacks, no sugary cereal, no soda. Even Honey Nut Cheerios were verboten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: M.L.B. Lockout: Players Reject Offer of Federal Mediation
description: “We don’t need mediation because what we are offering to M.L.B. is fair for both sides,” Max Scherzer said as various players started to speak out about delays.
content: With the prospect of spring training beginning in less than two weeks looking increasingly grim, Major League Baseball believed a stalemate in negotiations with the players’ union over a new labor deal could be broken with an outside mediator. So on Thursday, the league asked the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service for its help in what would have been a nonbinding and voluntary process that is meant to offer suggestions — not settlements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Joe Rogan Apologizes for ‘Shameful’ Past Use of Racial Slur
description: His apology came as listeners said that as many as 70 episodes of “The Joe Rogan Experience” podcast had been quietly taken off Spotify; the company has yet to comment on the reported removals.
content: As pressure has intensified on Spotify and its star podcaster Joe Rogan, listeners reported that the company had quietly removed dozens of episodes of his show, while Rogan apologized early Saturday for his use of a racial slur in past episodes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 5, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 5, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about the resignations of senior aides to Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain misstated the surname of Mr. Johnson’s chief of staff. It is Dan Rosenfield, not Rosenfeld.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Abortion Views, and Personal Stories
description: Readers’ responses to recent Opinion pieces include accounts of their own abortions and a grandmother’s death after an illegal procedure.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Republicans and a ‘Legitimate’ Riot
description: Readers are outraged by the G.O.P. description of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
